 FlowChart&view=100 World Resources Institute] for a detailed breakdown]]
 'Climate change mitigation' encompasses the actions being taken, and those that
 have been proposed, to limit the magnitude and/or rate of long-term global
 warming induced climate change. {{citation
 | at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch3s3-5.html 3.5
 | Interaction between mitigation and adaptation, in the light of climate change
 | impacts and decision-making under long-term uncertainty] author=Fisher, B.S.,
 | et al. chapter=Ch. 3: Issues related to mitigation in the long-term context
}}, in  Climate change mitigation generally involves reductions in human
(anthropogenic) emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs). {{citation
 | at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/spmsspm-c.html Table
 | SPM.3, C. Mitigation in the short and medium term (until 2030)]
 | chapter=Summary for policymakers chapter-
 | url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/spm.html author=IPCC
}}, in  Mitigation may also be achieved by increasing the capacity of
carbon sinks, e.g., through reforestation.
By contrast, adaptation to global warming are actions taken to manage the
eventual (or unavoidable) impacts of global warming,
[http://www.epa.gov/climatechange/glossary.html#A "Adaptation"], in  e.g.,
by building dikes in response to sea level rise. {{citation
 | author=Nicholls, R.J., et al. chapter=Ch 6: Coastal Systems and Low-Lying
 | Areas chapter-
 | url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch6.html at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg2/en/ch6s6-6-
 | 2.html Table 6.11]
}}, in 

Examples of mitigation include switching to low-carbon energy sources, such as
renewable and nuclear energy, and expanding forests and other "sinks" to remove
greater amounts of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Energy efficiency can also play a major role, {{citation
 | at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/mains5-5.html Sec 5.5
 | Technology flows and development] chapter=Synthesis report chapter-
 | url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/main.html
}}, in  for example, through improving the insulation of buildings.
{{citation
 | at=[http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/wg3/en/ch6s6-4-2.html Sec
 | 6.4.2 Thermal envelope] author=Levine, M., et al. chapter=Ch 6: Residential
 | and commercial buildings
}}, in 

Another approach to climate change mitigation is geoengineering.

 Most geoengineering techniques can be organized into two categories. {{citation
 | chapter=Ch 1: Introduction
}}, in  The first category is called solar radiation management, which
involves either reducing incoming sunlight, or increasing the reflectivity
(albedo) of the Earth's surface to sunlight.
The second category is called carbon dioxide removal, which involves reducing
the atmospheric concentration of carbon dioxide, e.g., by increasing the
capacity of the oceans to absorb carbon from the atmosphere. Scientific understanding of geoengineering is limited, and
there is the risk of unknown side-effects. {{citation
 | chapter=Evaluation of geoengineering methods, in: Summary
}}, in 

The main international treaty on climate change is the United Nations Framework
Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). {{citation
 | title=Introduction to the Convention author=UNFCCC
 | url=http://unfccc.int/key_steps/the_convention/items/6036.php
 | publisher=UNFCCC date=5 March 2013
}}  In 2010, Parties to the UNFCCC agreed that future global warming
should be limited to below 2.0 Â°C (3.6 Â°F) relative to the pre-
industrial level. {{citation
 | date=15 March 2011 author=UNFCCC. Conference of the Parties (COP)
 | title=Report of the Conference of the Parties on its sixteenth session, held
 | in Cancun from 29 November to 10 December 2010. Addendum. Part two: Action
 | taken by the Conference of the Parties at its sixteenth session
 | publisher=United Nations location=Geneva, Switzerland
 | url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2010/cop16/eng/07a01.pdf#page=2
}}, p.3, paragraph 4. Document [http://unfccc.int/documentation/documents/advan-
ced_search/items/6911.php?priref=600006173 available] in UN languages and text
format.  Analysis suggests that meeting the 2 Â°C target would require
annual global emissions of greenhouse gases The "Kyoto" basket of
greenhouse gases, measured in carbon dioxide equivalents. These gases are carbon
dioxide (), methane (), nitrous oxide (), sulphur hexafluoride (), and two
groups of gases: hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and perfluorocarbons (PFCs). . 
to peak before the year 2020, and decline significantly thereafter,
{{citation
 | chapter=Executive summary
}}, in .  with emissions in 2050 reduced by 30-50% compared to 1990
levels. Based on UNEP (2012) data. Based on expert judgement, this
reduction would give a greater than 66% chance of limiting warming to below
2.0 Â°C relative to the pre-industrial level. Estimates of the reductions
required vary between models. The median estimate is 16 gigatonnes (Gt) e,
which is equivalent to a reduction of about 43% compared to the 1990 level
(median emissions in 1990 = 37 Gte) . The 20th-80th percentile range is a
reduction of between 12-19 Gte (~51-32%). The full range is a reduction of
between 5-25 Gte (~14-68%). {{citation
 | chapter=Table 3.1 and fig 3.2 in: Ch 3: The Emissions Gap â An Update
}}, in .  Analyses by the United Nations Environment Programme
{{citation
 | chapter=Executive summary
}}, in .  and International Energy Agency {{citation
 | author=IEA title=World Energy Outlook 2012 chapter=Executive summary
 | publisher=Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) /
 | International Energy Agency (IEA) location=Paris, France
 | url=http://www.iea.org/publications/freepublications/publication/English.pdf
}}, p.1. [http://www.worldenergyoutlook.org/publications/weo-2012/ Executive
summaries] in Arabic, Chinese, French, German, Italian, Japanese, Korean,
Polish, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, and Turkish.  suggest that current
policies (as of 2012) are too weak to achieve the 2 Â°C target.
